melody.description: There is no melody or mood associated with this line, which may be because it is the preamble to the hymn, or is not meant to be read in any particular melody or mood

author.author: None
author.description: There is no author associated with this line, as it may be the preamble to the hymn

translation.text: The Unstruck Melody resounds and resonates in peaceful ease.

melody.description: Raag Majh was composed by the Fifth Sikh Guru (Shri Guru Arjun Dev ji). The Raag’s origins are based in Punjabi Folk Music and its essence was inspired by the Majha regions traditions of ‘Ausian’; the game of waiting and yearning for the return of a loved one.The feelings evoked by this Raag have often been compared to that of a mother waiting for her child to return after a long period of separation. She has an anticipation and hope for the child’s return, although at the same moment she is painfully aware of the uncertainty of their return home. This Raag brings to life the emotion of extreme love and this is highlighted by the sorrow and anguish of separation.

author.author: Guru Arjan Dev
author.description:
Guru Arjan Dev [1563 - 1606] was the fifth Guru of the Sikhs, born at Goindval. He was the youngest of the three sons of Guru Ram Das, the fourth Sikh Guru.

Guru Arjan Dev finished the construction of the Harimandir Sahib, the Golden Temple, and compiled the first Sikh scripture, known as the Adi Granth. Shortly after he became the first martyr of the Sikh religion, which formed a turning point in the development of the faith.

translation.text: I rejoice in the eternal bliss of the Word of the Shabad.

melody.description: Raag Majh was composed by the Fifth Sikh Guru (Shri Guru Arjun Dev ji). text: ਸਹਜ ਗੁਫਾ ਮਹਿ ਤਾੜੀ ਲਾਈ ਆਸਣੁ ਊਚ ਸਵਾਰਿਆ ਜੀਉ ॥੧॥

translation.text: In the cave of intuitive wisdom I sit, absorbed in the silent trance of the Primal Void. I have obtained my seat in the heavens. ||1||

transliteration.text: sahaj guphā mah tārī lāī āsan ūch savāriā jīu .1.

melody.description: Raag Majh was composed by the Fifth Sikh Guru (Shri Guru Arjun Dev ji). This Raag brings to life the emotion of extreme love and this is highlighted by the sorrow and anguish of separation.

text: ਫਿਰਿ ਘਿਰਿ ਅਪੁਨੇ ਗ੍ਰਿਹ ਮਹਿ ਆਇਆ ॥

translation.text: After wandering through many other homes and houses, I have returned to my own home,

transliteration.text: phir ghir apunē grih mah āiā .

translation.text: and I have found what I was longing for.

text: ਤ੍ਰਿਪਤਿ ਅਘਾਇ ਰਹਿਆ ਹੈ ਸੰਤਹੁ ਗੁਰਿ ਅਨਭਉ ਪੁਰਖੁ ਦਿਖਾਰਿਆ ਜੀਉ ॥੨॥

translation.text: I am satisfied and fulfilled; O Saints, the Guru has shown me the Fearless Lord God. ||2||

transliteration.text: tripat aghāi rahiā hai santah gur anabhau purakh dikhāriā jīu .2.

translation.text: He Himself is the King, and He Himself is the people.

translation.text: He Himself is in Nirvaanaa, and He Himself indulges in pleasures.

text: ਆਪੇ ਤਖਤਿ ਬਹੈ ਸਚੁ ਨਿਆਈ ਸਭ ਚੂਕੀ ਕੂਕ ਪੁਕਾਰਿਆ ਜੀਉ ॥੩॥

translation.text: He Himself sits on the throne of true justice, answering the cries and prayers of all. ||3||

transliteration.text: āpē takhat bahai sach niāī sabh chūkī kūk pukāriā jīu .3.

translation.text: As I have seen Him, so have I described Him.

text: ਤਿਸੁ ਰਸੁ ਆਇਆ ਜਿਨਿ ਭੇਦੁ ਲਹਿਆ ॥

translation.text: This Sublime Essence comes only to one who knows the Mystery of the Lord.

transliteration.text: tis ras āiā jin bhēd lahiā .

text: ਜੋਤੀ ਜੋਤਿ ਮਿਲੀ ਸੁਖੁ ਪਾਇਆ ਜਨ ਨਾਨਕ ਇਕੁ ਪਸਾਰਿਆ ਜੀਉ ॥੪॥੩॥੧੦॥

translation.text: His light merges into the Light, and he finds peace. O servant Nanak, this is all the Extension of the One. ||4||3||10||

transliteration.text: jōtī jōt milī sukh pāiā jan nānak ik pasāriā jīu .4.3.10.
